text.p: KLM Royal Dutch Airlines, unveiling a rise in first half net income on Tuesday, said its cargo capacity growth rate had been reduced and was now within range of traffic growth.
The overall cargo load factor in the second quarter fell 0.4 percentage points to 66.0 percent versus a 3.3 percentage point fall in the first quarter of the current 1996-97 fiscal year.
The intercontinental cargo load factor rose slightly in the second quarter versus a year-earlier, it said.
Cargo traffic revenues rose three percent in the July-September quarter.

Yield per revenue ton-kilometer (RTK) fell by three percent in guilders as a result of negative changes in product mix, in average distance flown and positive exchange rate differences of around two percent, KLM said.
Second quarter cargo traffic rose by six percent to 996 million RTKs, while capacity also increased by six percent to 1.51 billion available ton-kilometers (ATKs).
First half cargo traffic rose by four percent to 1.94 billion RTKs, while capacity increased by seven percent to 2.98 billion ATKs.
